title: International reactions to the 2016 United States presidential election
text:
International reactions to the November 8, 2016, election of <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a> emerged from around the world, including states, other institutions, and people.
States.
Africa.
Algeria.
<a href="President%20of%20Algeria">Algerian president</a> <a href="Abdelaziz%20Bouteflika">Abdelaziz Bouteflika</a> congratulated Trump, stressing the <a href="Algeria-United%20States%20relations">quality of friendship relations and cooperation between Algeria and the US</a>. He issued a statement saying: "The American people, through the presidential election of November 8, 2016, has given you their votes to become their president."
Egypt.
<a href="President%20of%20Egypt">President</a> <a href="Abdel%20Fattah%20el-Sisi">Abdel Fattah el-Sisi</a> congratulated Trump and said "Egypt is looking forward to seeing a new spirit brought to the presidential term of President Trump in terms of <a href="Egypt%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">Egyptian-American relations</a>, including more cooperation and coordination for the mutual benefit of the American and Egyptian people." The two had met during the opening of the <a href="seventy-first%20session%20of%20the%20United%20Nations%20General%20Assembly">seventy-first session of the United Nations General Assembly</a>. A statement from his office read that he had personally congratulated Trump during a telephone call and that he was the first world leader to do so. "The U.S. president-elect Donald Trump expressed his utmost appreciation to the president, pointing out that his was the first international call he had received to congratulate him on winning the election." The result was also welcomed by many Egyptian <a href="Parliament%20of%20Egypt">members of Parliament</a>. Later, el-Sisi stated that Trump's actions as US president would likely be different from his rhetoric prior to the election, saying "let's not jump into conclusions or worry".
Kenya.
<a href="President%20of%20Kenya">President</a> <a href="Uhuru%20Kenyatta">Uhuru Kenyatta</a> sent a congratulatory message to Trump and said:
The American people have spoken, and they have spoken clearly. The <a href="Kenya-United%20States%20relations">ties that bind Kenya and the United States of America</a> are close and strong. They are old and based on the values that we hold dear: in democracy, in the rule of law, and in the equality of peoples.
Mauritius.
<a href="President%20of%20Mauritius">Mauritian president</a> <a href="Ameenah%20Gurib">Ameenah Gurib</a> wrote on Twitter: "#Donald Trump's victory isn't the most terrifying news today. There's something even worse." She posted an article from "<a href="The%20Independent">The Independent</a>" with the heading "Climate change may be escalating so fast it could be 'game over', scientists warn."
Morocco.
King <a href="Mohammed%20VI%20of%20Morocco">Mohammed VI</a> sent a message of congratulations to Trump and expressed his best wishes for the success of the Trump administration to lead the American people towards further progress and prosperity. He said he wanted to <a href="Morocco-United%20States%20relations">enhance dialogue, coordination and consultation</a> particularly in security to "counter all forms of extremism, violence and terrorism and to help find peaceful solutions to conflicts and tensions around the globe." He also expressed his appreciation for the United States' "continued support and keen interest in the major structural reforms initiated in the kingdom with a view to promoting Morocco's comprehensive development, as well as in efforts aimed at achieving peace and stability in the region."
Nigeria.
<a href="President%20of%20Nigeria">Nigerian president</a> <a href="Muhammadu%20Buhari">Muhammadu Buhari</a> congratulated Trump and American citizens. He also stated he looked forward to working together to <a href="Nigeria-United%20States%20relations">strengthen friendly relations between Nigeria and the US</a>.
Seychelles.
Seychellois president <a href="Danny%20Faure">Danny Faure</a> congratulated Trump. In a statement, he wished Trump "every success as he prepares to discharge the important duties which lay ahead" and also highlighted what he termed as <a href="Seychelles-United%20States%20relations">"excellent and steady progression in cooperation" in various fields of interest between Seychelles and the US</a>.
Somalia.
<a href="President%20of%20Somalia">Somalian president</a> <a href="Hassan%20Sheikh%20Mohamud">Hassan Sheikh Mohamud</a> congratulated Trump and looks forward to improve further diplomatic relations between <a href="United%20States-Somalia%20relations">Somalia and the United States</a>.
South Africa.
<a href="President%20of%20South%20Africa">President</a> <a href="Jacob%20Zuma">Jacob Zuma</a> congratulated Trump and conveyed his best wishes. He also looked forward to working with Trump to <a href="South%20Africa-United%20States%20relations">build on the strong relations that exist between the two countries</a>. He underlined that "South Africa further looked forward to working closely with the new administration in the United States in promoting peace, security, and prosperity around the world, especially on the African continent."
Sudan.
President <a href="Omar%20al-Bashir">Omar al-Bashir</a> congratulated Trump as a Trump adviser had pledged to not lift sanctions on the east African country. Al-Bashir said, "I am pleased to extend to Your Excellency in my name and on behalf of the Government and [the] people of the Republic of Sudan warmest and most sincere congratulations on your election as President of the United States of America." He further expressed that he was looking forward to working with Trump to "<a href="Sudan-United%20States%20relations">upgrade relations between our two friendly countries</a>."
Tanzania.
<a href="President%20of%20Tanzania">Tanzanian president</a> <a href="John%20Pombe%20Magufuli">John Pombe Magufuli</a> congratulated Trump via Twitter and assured him of continued <a href="Tanzania-United%20States%20relations">friendship and cooperation of his country with the US</a>.
Uganda.
<a href="President%20of%20Uganda">Ugandan president</a> <a href="Yoweri%20Museveni">Yoweri Museveni</a> congratulated Trump by writing on Twitter: "I look forward to working with him like I have done with his predecessors."
Zimbabwe.
Information and Communication Minister <a href="Chris%20Mushohwe">Chris Mushohwe</a> hoped the new US administration would <a href="United%20States-Zimbabwe%20relations">"restore sound relations between Harare and Washington"</a>. He added: "Zimbabwe respects the wishes of the people of America ... Our country has never had any quarrel with America and does [not] need to have any quarrel with them." He further hoped Trump would "restore our relationship and we will never become an enemy of America."
Other.
<a href="Burundi">Burundi</a>an president <a href="Pierre%20Nkurunziza">Pierre Nkurunziza</a> and <a href="President%20of%20Ghana">Ghanaian President</a> <a href="John%20Dramani%20Mahama">John Dramani Mahama</a> posted their Twitter messages congratulating Trump.
Asia.
Afghanistan.
<a href="President%20of%20Afghanistan">President</a> <a href="Ashraf%20Ghani">Ashraf Ghani</a> congratulated Trump and said that <a href="Afghanistan-United%20States%20relations">relations between the two states would further improve</a> under him.
Armenia.
<a href="President%20of%20Armenia">Armenian president</a> <a href="Serzh%20Sargsyan">Serzh Sargsyan</a> congratulated Trump and wrote "I have no doubt, that under your able leadership the United States will achieve further progress and advancement in the years to come."
Azerbaijan.
<a href="President%20of%20Azerbaijan">Azerbaijani president</a> <a href="Ilham%20Aliyev">Ilham Aliyev</a> congratulated Trump in a statement that read: "I extend to You my sincere congratulations on your election as President of the United States of America. Your victory in the election is indicative of the confidence in and support for You of the friendly people of the United States."
Bahrain.
Bahraini prince <a href="Salman%20bin%20Hamad%20Al%20Khalifa">Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa</a> sent a <a href="diplomatic%20cable">diplomatic cable</a> of congratulations and good wishes to Trump and wished him more success and expressed Bahrain's aspiration to "<a href="Bahrain-United%20States%20relations">boost and consolidate the distinctive historic ties</a> between the two countries and peoples and to develop the bilateral cooperation in all fields."
Bangladesh.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Bangladesh">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Sheikh%20Hasina">Sheikh Hasina</a> issued a statement to congratulate Trump, saying:
I am confident that under your leadership, the existing bilateral relation between our two friendly nations would be further strengthened. I look forward to working closely with you for advancing our bilateral and multilateral interests and contributing to create a safe and secured world, where our coming generations could live and continue to prosper peacefully. I cordially invite you and Mrs Melania Trump to visit Bangladesh at a mutually convenient time and see for yourself the phenomenal development that took place in Bangladesh in the recent years.
Cambodia.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Cambodia">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Hun%20Sen">Hun Sen</a> congratulated Trump saying:
I would like to congratulate His Excellency Donald Trump for achieving victory in the US presidential election ... American voters have shown their choice to elect your excellency ... My support for your candidacy is not wrong either.
China.
<a href="President%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">President</a> <a href="Xi%20Jinping">Xi Jinping</a> congratulated Trump and said he looked forward to working together to <a href="China-United%20States%20relations">promote ties</a> in a "constructive" way to avoid conflict and confrontation. He added that both countries shared common interests and shouldered a "special and important responsibility in upholding world peace. I highly value China-U.S. relations and am looking forward to working with you to expand cooperation in all fields, including in bilateral, regional and global aspects." He says he expects they would "manage differences in a constructive way, in the spirit of non-conflict, non-confrontation, mutual respect, cooperation and win-win." In a phone conversation with Trump, Xi said that cooperation was "the only correct choice." A statement from Trump's presidential transition office read that "the leaders established a clear sense of mutual respect for one another."
India.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20India">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Narendra%20Modi">Narendra Modi</a> congratulated Trump and wrote that "we appreciated the friendship you have articulated toward India during your campaign." He added that he looks forward to working with him. During a campaign rally to woo <a href="Indian-Americans">Indian-Americans</a>, Trump adapted a slogan from Modi's own campaign that changed from ""ab ki baar, Modi Sarkar" to "ab ki baar, Trump sarkar"" (now is the time for a Modi/Trump government).
Indonesia.
<a href="President%20of%20Indonesia">President</a> <a href="Joko%20Widodo">Joko Widodo</a> congratulated Trump and said that "Indonesia will continue its mutually beneficial cooperation with the United States." He also invited Trump "to continue to work together to build peace and create prosperity for the world" and further added that he remained "optimistic about <a href="Indonesia-United%20States%20relations">United States-Indonesia relations</a> under a Donald Trump presidency."
Iran.
<a href="President%20of%20Iran">President</a> <a href="Hassan%20Rouhani">Hassan Rouhani</a> said the result would not change his country's policies. He added, in reference to Trump's administration possibly distancing the US from the rest of the world, that: "The position of the United States has been weakened within the international community and in the world's public opinion as a result of wrongful policies, and a wider gap with the global community and Europe will further harm that position." He also said that the US could not spread Iranophobia as forcefully anymore in order to get international consensus against Iran. "The Islamic Republic's policy of constructive interaction with the world and breaking up nuclear sanctions, has placed Iran's economic ties with all countries on an improving and irreversible course." He noted that the <a href="JCPOA">JCPOA</a> was an agreement with one country or government but was approved by the <a href="UN%20Security%20Council%20Resolution">UN Security Council Resolution</a> and thus could not be overturned unilaterally.
Israel.
<a href="President%20of%20Israel">President</a> <a href="Reuven%20Rivlin">Reuven Rivlin</a> congratulated Trump. He added: "I hope together Israelis and Americans can grow our innovation and cooperation, which are the fruits of liberty, and equality."
Kazakhstan.
<a href="President%20of%20Kazakhstan">Kazakhstani president</a> <a href="Nursultan%20Nazarbayev">Nursultan Nazarbayev</a> congratulated Trump wishing him success, invited him to visit Kazakhstan, and added: "I believe that under your leadership the United States will remain a mainstay in maintaining stability, security and prosperity throughout the world."
Kuwait.
Kuwaiti emir <a href="Sabah%20Al-Ahmad%20Al-Jaber%20Al-Sabah">Sheikh al-Sabah</a> sent his congratulations to Trump and "expressed hopes that <a href="Kuwait-United%20States%20relations">Kuwait and the U.S. will continue their strong historic relations</a>, working together for a brighter future for the world."
Lebanon.
Newly elected <a href="President%20of%20Lebanon">president</a> <a href="Michel%20Aoun">Michel Aoun</a> congratulated Trump and expressed hope for <a href="Lebanon-United%20States%20relations">strengthening cooperation between Lebanon and the United States</a>. Aoun said, "It is with great pleasure I congratulate you on your election as President of the United States of America, the great country which is tied to Lebanon through friendship and mutual respect."
Malaysia.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Malaysia">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Najib%20Razak">Najib Razak</a> congratulated US president-elect Donald Trump, saying the Republican victor had appealed to Americans who wanted to see the United States less embroiled in intervention abroad. Najib said he looked forward to continuing a partnership with the United States under Trump's presidency.
Maldives.
<a href="President%20of%20the%20Maldives">President</a> <a href="Abdulla%20Yameen">Abdulla Yameen</a> congratulated Trump on his victory. In his message, he said "I remain confident that the existing ties of friendship and cooperation between our two countries will continue and further strengthen under your able leadership. I also look forward to working with you not only to develop closer relations between our countries but also to concert on advancement of global interests common to our countries". The president also said that he support Trump's policy of "no-interference" on other countries affairs. He added "Today, America elected its new President. The strongest policy he has announced so far is to stop America's efforts to meddle in global affairs. America needs to stop policing the entire world. This, without a doubt, is a very good principle".
Myanmar.
President's office deputy-director and spokesman for <a href="President%20of%20Myanmar">Myanmar president</a> <a href="Htin%20Kyaw">Htin Kyaw</a>, <a href="Zaw%20Htay">Zaw Htay</a> said: "I believe that the <a href="Myanmar-United%20States%20relations">relationship between the U.S.A. and Burma (Myanmar)</a> can only get better under President Trump." Following Trump's win, Zaw congratulated him on "Facebook" by writing: "Best wishes for you to make America Great Again!"
North Korea.
Kim Yong Ho, director of human rights and humanitarian issues, stated on behalf of the country, "We do not care about whoever becomes the president of the United States, the fundamental issue here is whether or not the United States has the political will to withdraw its <a href="North%20Korea%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">hostile policy toward the DPRK</a>".
Pakistan.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Pakistan">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Nawaz%20Sharif">Nawaz Sharif</a> congratulated Trump on his "historic victory." Sharif stated: "On behalf of the government and people of Pakistan, and on my own behalf, I wish to extend to you and the people of the United States, our most sincere felicitations on your election as the 45th president of the United States. Most importantly, your momentous success is a testimony to the confidence that the people of the United States have reposed in your leadership, vision and commitment to serve your great country." He added <a href="Pakistan-United%20States%20relations">Pakistan and the United States have enjoyed a strategic partnership</a>, rooted in the shared ideals of freedom, democracy, mutual respect, and commonality of interests. "I wish to re-affirm my government's commitment to further strengthening and deepening of our relations, in a manner truly reflective of the aspirations of our two nations. I am looking forward to closely working with you, to bring our two countries closer and making our partnership an important vehicle for the realization of peace, security and prosperity in the region and beyond."
Palestine.
<a href="President%20of%20the%20State%20of%20Palestine">President</a> <a href="Mahmoud%20Abbas">Mahmoud Abbas</a> hoped the <a href="Middle%20East%20peace%20process">Middle East peace process</a> "will be achieved" during Trump's presidency and also congratulated him.
Philippines.
<a href="President%20of%20the%20Philippines">President</a> <a href="Rodrigo%20Duterte">Rodrigo Duterte</a> offered "warm congratulations" to Trump and looks forward to working with him to <a href="Philippines%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">enhance relations</a>, according to a statement by <a href="Presidential%20Communications%20Group%20%28Philippines%29">Presidential Communications Secretary</a> <a href="Martin%20Andanar">Martin Andanar</a>. Duterte also told a gathering of <a href="Filipino%20people">Filipinos</a> in <a href="Kuala%20Lumpur">Kuala Lumpur</a> during his <a href="International%20presidential%20trips%20made%20by%20Rodrigo%20Duterte">Malaysian visit</a> said that he "[does not] want to fight because Trump is there." (Duterte previously had a war of words with incumbent US President <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> due to the latter's criticism of Duterte's <a href="Philippine%20Drug%20War">war on drugs</a>.) He then congratulated Trump and greeted him: ""<a href="Mabuhay">Mabuhay</a> ka!" ["May you live!"]".
Saudi Arabia.
<a href="King%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">King</a> <a href="Salman%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud</a> congratulated Trump and affirmed Saudi Arabia's aspiration to <a href="Saudi%20Arabia-United%20States%20relations">promote the historical and strategic relations with the United States</a> and work together to bring peace and stability to the Middle East and the world, as well-wishing the American people further progress and prosperity under his leadership.
Singapore.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Singapore">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Lee%20Hsien%20Loong">Lee Hsien Loong</a> congratulated Trump saying "voters have elected a president whom they feel best represents them and Singapore fully respects their decision." He added that Singapore will continue to work together with the United States to <a href="Singapore-United%20States%20relations">cultivate strong ties</a>.
South Korea.
<a href="President%20of%20South%20Korea">President</a> <a href="Park%20Geun-hye">Park Geun-hye</a> congratulated Trump saying she "hopes for further closer cooperation between the two nations on North Korea's nuclear issue to maintain the peace and stability on the <a href="Korean%20Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, in Northeast Asia and beyond on the back of the deepening and developing alliance" according to Presidential Spokesman Jung Youn-kuk.
Sri Lanka.
<a href="President%20of%20Sri%20Lanka">President</a> <a href="Maithripala%20Sirisena">Maithripala Sirisena</a> wrote on Twitter congratulating Trump: "My warm congratulations to US president-elect Donald J. Trump on this historic victory."
Syria.
<a href="President%20of%20Syria">President</a> <a href="Bashar%20al-Assad">Bashar al-Assad</a> said that he was "ready" to cooperate with the incoming Trump administration.
Taiwan.
<a href="President%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20China">President</a> <a href="Tsai%20Ing-wen">Tsai Ing-wen</a> sent a letter of congratulations to Trump and stated that under his leadership <a href="Taiwan%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">relations between Taiwan and the United States</a> are certain to grow even stronger in the years to come. On December 2, 2016, US President-Elect <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a> accepted <a href="Trump-Tsai%20call">a congratulatory phone call</a> from Taiwanese President <a href="Tsai%20Ing-Wen">Tsai Ing-Wen</a>, which was the first time since 1979 that a US <a href="President-Elect">President-Elect</a> has publicly spoken to the President of Taiwan.
Thailand.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Thailand">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Prayut%20Chan-o-cha">Prayut Chan-o-cha</a> extended his congratulations to Trump saying:
We have to adjust to change. Things keep changing. I have not been indifferent to change. Instead, I have been keeping abreast of it.
Turkey.
... in essence our relations are relations between two states and we hope that under the new presidential term the Turkish-U.S. relations will be much better. That is our expectation. I saw an intense campaign for Hillary Clinton's victory. Artists, sportsmen, all personalities worked for Clinton's victory. But in elections, it is important to embrace the people. No one has won elections through newspaper headlines, opinion polls or television (campaigns).
United Arab Emirates.
<a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20Arab%20Emirates">President</a> <a href="Sheikh%20Khalifa">Sheikh Khalifa</a> congratulated Trump and wished him "success in his future tasks." He also commended the <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates-United%20States%20relations">strategic ties between the two countries and emphasised the U.A.E.'s desire to strengthen those relations</a>.
Vice President and Emir of Dubai Sheikh <a href="Mohammed%20bin%20Rashid%20Al%20Maktoum">Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum</a> also offered his congratulations to Trump.
Other.
<a href="Brunei">Brunei</a>an <a href="List%20of%20Sultans%20of%20Brunei">sultan</a> <a href="Hassanal%20Bolkiah">Hassanal Bolkiah</a>, <a href="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a>i <a href="President%20of%20Kyrgyzstan">president</a> <a href="Almazbek%20Atambayev">Almazbek Atambayev</a>, <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>ese <a href="President%20of%20Vietnam">president</a> <a href="Tr%E1%BA%A7n%20%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i%20Quang">Trần Đại Quang</a> and <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Vietnam">Vietnamese prime minister</a> <a href="Nguy%E1%BB%85n%20Xu%C3%A2n%20Ph%C3%BAc">Nguyễn Xuân Phúc</a> sent congratulatory messages to Trump. <a href="Qatar">Qatar</a>i <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Qatar%29">minister of foreign affairs</a> <a href="Mohammed%20bin%20Abdulrahman%20Al%20Thani">Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani</a> congratulated Trump via Twitter. <a href="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>i <a href="President%20of%20Tajikistan">president</a> <a href="Emomali%20Rahmon">Emomali Rahmon</a> congratulated Trump and hoped for <a href="Tajikistan-United%20States%20relations">further expansion of cooperation and partnership</a> with the United States under his term.
Europe.
Austria.
<a href="Norbert%20Hofer">Norbert Hofer</a>, the third president of the <a href="National%20Council%20%28Austria%29">National Council</a> and the <a href="Freedom%20Party%20of%20Austria">Austrian Freedom Party</a>'s candidate for president <a href="Austrian%20presidential%20election%2C%202016">in 2016</a>, supported Trump, remarking "Wherever the elites distance themselves from voters, those elites will be voted out of office."
Belarus.
<a href="President%20of%20Belarus">Belarusian president</a> <a href="Alexander%20Lukashenko">Alexander Lukashenko</a> sent his greetings to Trump saying: "Your active, sincere, and courageous position during the election campaign inspired the American society, returned it to true democracy."
Cyprus.
<a href="President%20of%20Cyprus">President</a> <a href="Nicos%20Anastasiades">Nicos Anastasiades</a> wrote on Twitter: "Congratulations to [Donald Trump] on winning the U.S. presidential election. My wishes for a most successful and productive term in Office." In a statement added to the message, he added:
Under your leadership, the Republic of Cyprus looks forward to <a href="Cyprus-United%20States%20relations">deepening its strategic partnership with the US</a>. The Cyprus-led and Cyprus-owned <a href="Reunification%20of%20Cyprus">negotiations to reunify Cyprus</a> are taking place in an even more intensified format. As a Permanent Member of the UN Security Council, the US plays a pivotal role is ["<a href="sic">sic</a>"] assisting our efforts towards ending Turkey's military occupation and reunifying Cyprus for the benefit of all Cypriots.
Czech Republic.
<a href="President%20of%20the%20Czech%20Republic">President</a> <a href="Milo%C5%A1%20Zeman">Miloš Zeman</a> congratulated Trump and noted that he "shares his views" and "appreciates Trump's public demeanor". Zeman also invited Trump for <a href="state%20visit">state visit</a> to the capital, <a href="Prague">Prague</a>. His Spokesman Jiří Ovčáček had earlier said that "average Americans managed to beat pseudo-elites and the lying media." Zeman had previously endorsed Trump.
Denmark.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Denmark">Danish prime minister</a> <a href="Lars%20L%C3%B8kke%20Rasmussen">Lars Løkke Rasmussen</a> released a statement that read Trump was elected after an unusually fierce and confrontational campaign. He also congratulated Trump and expressed a hope for continued good relations between <a href="United%20States%E2%80%93European%20Union%20relations">Europe and the US</a>.
Finland.
<a href="President%20of%20Finland">Finnish president</a> <a href="Sauli%20Niinist%C3%B6">Sauli Niinistö</a> congratulated Trump and wished him luck and "wisdom in his significant duties." He also highlighted the international tension and the role of the president of the United States in shaping the world.
France.
<a href="President%20of%20France">President</a> <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20Hollande">François Hollande</a> says the election "opens a period of uncertainty. It must be faced with lucidity and clarity." He also congratulated Trump "as is natural between two heads of state [but] certain positions taken by Donald Trump during the American campaign must be confronted with the values and interests we share with the United States. What is at stake is peace, the fight against terrorism, the situation in the Middle East. It is economic relations and the preservation of the planet." He had previously endorsed Clinton.
Germany.
<a href="President%20of%20Germany">President</a> <a href="Joachim%20Gauck">Joachim Gauck</a> congratulated Trump on his victory, although a few days before he expressed concerns over him being elected.
Greece.
<a href="President%20of%20Greece">President</a> <a href="Prokopis%20Pavlopoulos">Prokopis Pavlopoulos</a> sent a congratulatory message stating:
Holy See.
<a href="Pope%20Francis">Pope Francis</a> on Twitter called for "dialogue, mutual acceptance and fraternal cooperation" after the election. <a href="Vatican%20Secretary%20of%20State">Vatican secretary of state</a> Cardinal <a href="Pietro%20Parolin">Pietro Parolin</a> expressed respect for the will of the people, noting the strong election turnout. He wished that Trump, whose wife would be the second Roman Catholic <a href="First%20Lady%20of%20the%20United%20States">first lady</a>, could serve towards the well-being of his people and the furtherance of world peace.
Hungary.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Hungary">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Viktor%20Orb%C3%A1n">Viktor Orbán</a> sent a congratulatory message in a "Facebook" post. "What great news. Democracy is still alive." Speaking at a business conference on 10 November, Orbán said: "Western civilization has successfully liberated itself from the captivity of an ideology" with the election of Trump "and return to reality." He also called the past 25 years in the world as "liberal non-democracy" which ended after Brexit and Trump's victory.
Iceland.
<a href="President%20of%20Iceland">President</a> <a href="Gu%C3%B0ni%20Th.%20J%C3%B3hannesson">Guðni Th. Jóhannesson</a> sent his congratulations to Trump. In his statement, Guðni had caveats that Icelanders value the concepts of equality and tolerance. "The President emphasised in his statement the <a href="Iceland%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">cooperation and friendship between the two countries</a>, and the long common history that stretches all the way back to when seafarers from Iceland and Greenland landed in North America more than a thousand years ago. Even though the United States is one of the largest democracies in the world, and Iceland one of the smallest, these nations share many important values. We unconditionally support the right to freedom of thought and expression, gender equality, and highly value equal rights for all regardless of race or religion."
Ireland.
<a href="President%20of%20Ireland">President</a> <a href="Michael%20D.%20Higgins">Michael D. Higgins</a> spoke of the "<a href="Ireland%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">deep connection</a>" between Ireland and the United States, conveying "best wishes to President Elect Donald Trump, wishing him and the American people every good fortune for his term in office." <a href="Taoiseach">Taoiseach</a> <a href="Enda%20Kenny">Enda Kenny</a>, who had previously condemned Trump's rhetoric as "racist and divisive", was among the first world leaders to speak with Trump on the phone and offer congratulations, and confirmed that the annual <a href="St.%20Patrick%27s%20Day">St. Patrick's Day</a> ceremony at the White House, which has occurred since 1952, would continue under the new administration.
Italy.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Italy">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Matteo%20Renzi">Matteo Renzi</a> vowed to <a href="Italy-United%20States%20relations">maintain strong and friendly ties</a> between Italy and the United States and said that the <a href="international%20community">international community</a> should consider Trump's election as a new starting point.
Lithuania.
Reflecting <a href="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>'s history of being <a href="Occupation%20of%20the%20Baltic%20states">annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940</a> and his fears that "Russian president <a href="Vladimir%20Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> may test <a href="NATO">NATO</a> in the weeks before Donald Trump becomes US President", and that Putin and Trump are "too close for comfort", <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Lithuania%29">Lithuanian foreign minister</a> <a href="Linas%20Antanas%20Linkevi%C4%8Dius">Linas Linkevicius</a> has said that he is very afraid for the <a href="Baltic%20Republics">Baltic Republics</a> (NATO members Lithuania, <a href="Latvia">Latvia</a>, and <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a>), as well as for the <a href="Syria">Syria</a>n city of <a href="Aleppo">Aleppo</a> (a reference to Russia's involvement in the ongoing <a href="Battle%20of%20Aleppo%20%282012%E2%80%93present%29">Battle of Aleppo</a> in the <a href="Syrian%20Civil%20War">Syrian Civil War</a>).
Malta.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Malta">Maltese prime minister</a> <a href="Joseph%20Muscat">Joseph Muscat</a>, while in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> for a seminar, wrote: "I congratulate US president-elect Donald Trump. Now it is time for Europe and US to get closer to each other and not the other way around."
Netherlands.
Generally Dutch politicians reacted disappointed or even shocked by Trump's victory. <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20Netherlands">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Mark%20Rutte">Mark Rutte</a> phoned President-elect Trump on the evening of his election, congratulating him. Rutte and Trump both stressed the importance of continued close cooperation between the US and the Netherlands, being loyal allies and good friends. "The historical, cultural and economic ties between our countries are strong and we reaffirmed that in our conversation", said Rutte. He continued stating that the strong <a href="Netherlands%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">Dutch-American relationship</a> provides many jobs on both sides of the Atlantic and that cooperation is necessary to address common problems. Rutte looks forward to continue working together with Trump towards a safe and prosperous world and a strong EU-US relationship".
Norway.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Norway">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Erna%20Solberg">Erna Solberg</a> said at a press conference:
I would like to congratulate Donald Trump on his election victory. The US is our closest ally and <a href="Norway%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">our cooperation</a> is based on shared values and interests. We will seek to cooperate constructively with Donald Trump and with his administration once it is in place.
Portugal.
<a href="President%20of%20Portugal">President</a> <a href="Marcelo%20Rebelo%20de%20Sousa">Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa</a> sent Trump a message of congratulations and wished him success. He also made reference to the "<a href="Portugal-United%20States%20relations">bonds of friendship that unite Portugal and the U.S.A.</a> and the significant community of Portuguese and <a href="Portuguese%20Americans">Luso-Americans</a> in the United States."
Russia.
<a href="President%20of%20Russia">President</a> <a href="Vladimir%20Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> congratulated Trump and said: "The current <a href="Russia-United%20States%20relations">US–Russian relations</a> cannot be called friendly. Hopefully, with the new U.S. president a more constructive dialogue will be possible between our countries."
Serbia.
<a href="President%20of%20Serbia">President</a> <a href="Tomislav%20Nikoli%C4%87">Tomislav Nikolić</a> congratulated Trump and said: "We must make additional efforts to establish even more <a href="Serbia-United%20States%20relations">friendly relations with the United States</a>." 
I take this opportunity to express my sincere congratulations on your election success and the great victory in the presidential election. I believe you will approach your duties as the 45th president of the United States with the dedication and determination that characterized also your remarkable campaign. The leadership that you have shown on this occasion, represents a strong will that is necessary not only to citizens of the United States, but also to the whole world. I sincerely hope that your victory will contribute to continuing improvement of bilateral relations between Serbia and the United States, which are already on the path of progress and development, to the mutual benefit of our two countries.
Spain.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Spain">Spanish prime minister</a> <a href="Mariano%20Rajoy">Mariano Rajoy</a> wrote on Twitter congratulating Trump and tweeted that "we'll continue to work to <a href="Spain-United%20States%20relations">strengthen relations</a> that we have with [the] US, an indispensable partner."
Switzerland.
Government spokesperson <a href="Andr%C3%A9%20Simonazzi">André Simonazzi</a> said: "The Swiss government has taken note of the election results in the United States. As is customary, the <a href="President%20of%20the%20Swiss%20Confederation">Swiss president</a> sent congratulations through diplomatic channels this morning." He added that the Swiss authorities have been in touch with the teams of both candidates for the presidency in the run-up to prepare the next steps. "Switzerland will continue to defend its interests and prepare for contact with the new administration."
United Kingdom.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Theresa%20May">Theresa May</a> congratulated Trump. In relation to <a href="Brexit">Brexit</a>, she invoked the so-called "<a href="Special%20Relationship">Special Relationship</a>" stating that the two countries would remain "strong and close partners on trade, security and defence."
<a href="Crown%20dependencies">British Crown dependencies</a>.
<a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20the%20Isle%20of%20Man">Chief Minister</a> of <a href="Isle%20of%20Man">Isle of Man</a> <a href="Howard%20Quayle">Howard Quayle</a> said although Trump made clear his use of offshore jurisdictions, there is no scope for complacency in the drive to establish tax transparency. He said he firmly believes first-rate regulatory compliance and adherence to information-exchange agreements will set the Island above vilification. Through campaign, Trump had made no apology for refusing to disclose his federal tax payments, instead saying "that makes me smart." However, he had previously said tax avoidance was a substantial global problem and made worse by legal offshore structures.
Other.
<a href="Albania">Albania</a>n <a href="President%20of%20Albania">president</a> <a href="Bujar%20Nishani">Bujar Nishani</a>, <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>n <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Croatia">prime minister</a> <a href="Andrej%20Plenkovi%C4%87">Andrej Plenković</a>, and <a href="Poland">Polish</a> <a href="President%20of%20Poland">president</a> <a href="Andrzej%20Duda">Andrzej Duda</a> congratulated Trump on his victory.
<a href="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>n <a href="President%20of%20Slovenia">president</a> <a href="Borut%20Pahor">Borut Pahor</a> congratulated Trump and his Slovenian-born wife <a href="Melania%20Trump">Melania Trump</a> on Twitter.
North America.
Canada.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Canada">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Justin%20Trudeau">Justin Trudeau</a>'s office declined to comment until a winner was declared. At a US embassy party on election night, <a href="Minister%20of%20Finance%20%28Canada%29">Finance Minister</a> <a href="Bill%20Morneau">Bill Morneau</a> and <a href="Minister%20of%20Environment%20and%20Climate%20Change%20%28Canada%29">Environment Minister</a> <a href="Catherine%20McKenna">Catherine McKenna</a> arrived and left without making any comments. Trudeau later wrote on <a href="Facebook">Facebook</a>:
I congratulate President-elect Donald Trump on his election victory in the United States. Our shared values are strong. Our common purpose is to build countries where everyone has a fair chance to succeed, and where the government works first, foremost and always for the people it governs. The Canadian government will continue its hard work toward these ends, and we offer our hand in partnership with our neighbours as friends and allies as they move forward.
Cuba.
<a href="President%20of%20Cuba">President</a> <a href="Raul%20Castro">Raul Castro</a> sent his greetings to Trump upon his election.
Dominican Republic.
Minister of the Dominican Republic José Ramón Peralta said the country would continue to <a href="Dominican%20Republic-United%20States%20relations">strengthen trade and diplomatic ties with the US</a>.
Mexico.
<a href="President%20of%20Mexico">Mexican president</a> <a href="Enrique%20Pe%C3%B1a%20Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a> congratulated Trump via Twitter writing: "Mexico and the U.S. are friends, partners and allies who should continue working for the competitiveness and the development of North America."
Nicaragua.
<a href="President%20of%20Nicaragua">Nicaraguan president</a> <a href="Daniel%20Ortega">Daniel Ortega</a> sent a message to Trump saluting his electoral triumph on behalf of the Nicaraguan people and the government saying:
We join those who believe that it is possible to work with the United States to contribute to a world that privileges dialogue and understanding to attend the serious problems that affect humanity prioritizing peace. From our dignified and free Nicaragua which works in Christianity, Socialism and Solidarity, I greet you, your family and your people.
Oceania.
Australia.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Australia">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Malcolm%20Turnbull">Malcolm Turnbull</a> congratulated Trump, as well as thanked outgoing President <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> for his leadership over the past eight years. He also said that the US was "a great and powerful nation and they are a great and powerful friend." 
Fiji.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Fiji">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Frank%20Bainimarama">Frank Bainimarama</a> congratulated Trump, while also taking the opportunity to emphasise that action on climate change is a priority for Fiji:
Fiji <a href="Fiji-United%20States%20relations">has a close relationship with the United States</a> and I look forward to working with you and your administration in the months and years ahead. We especially seek America's support in our struggle against the extreme weather events and rising sea levels caused by climate change, which pose a particular threat to the Pacific islands and other low lying areas of the world. We also look forward to working with you to protect our oceans and seas from the threat of pollution and overfishing. With every best wish as you prepare to assume the presidency.
New Zealand.
<a href="Minister%20of%20Economic%20Development%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Economic Development Minister</a> <a href="Steven%20Joyce">Steven Joyce</a>, on behalf of <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20New%20Zealand">Prime Minister</a> <a href="John%20Key">John Key</a>, <a href="motion%20%28parliamentary%20procedure%29">moved</a> in the <a href="New%20Zealand%20House%20of%20Representatives">House of Representatives</a> "that the House convey its congratulations to President-elect Donald Trump on his election as the next president of the United States, and to Vice President–elect <a href="Mike%20Pence">Mike Pence</a> on his election, and in doing so express our desire to work with the incoming Trump Administration to continue building on New Zealand's already <a href="New%20Zealand%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">strong relationship with the United States</a>." The motion was agreed to 106 votes to 14, with the <a href="Green%20Party%20of%20Aotearoa%20New%20Zealand">Green Party</a> opposing.
Papua New Guinea.
<a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Papua%20New%20Guinea">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Peter%20O%27Neill">Peter O'Neill</a> extended his congratulations to Trump on behalf of the people of Papua New Guinea. In a statement that read "the result of the election is a decision of the American people and Papua New Guinea will work with the elected government of the day, as we do in every partner nation." He also congratulated Clinton for her hard-fought campaign and thanked her for her relationship with Papua New Guinea as well for her inspiration to women and girls around the world.
South America.
Argentina.
Argentine <a href="Chancellor%23Foreign%20minister">chancellor</a> <a href="Susana%20Malcorra">Susana Malcorra</a> congratulated Trump for his victory, but also regretted that the US did not elect a female president for the first time. <a href="President%20of%20Argentina">Argentine President</a> <a href="Mauricio%20Macri">Mauricio Macri</a> also congratulated him shortly afterwards.
Brazil.
<a href="President%20of%20Brazil">Brazilian president</a> <a href="Michel%20Temer">Michel Temer</a> issued a statement that read Trump's election will not change the <a href="Brazil-United%20States%20relations">relationship between the two countries</a> that is "institutional" and "from State to State."
Colombia.
<a href="President%20of%20Colombia">President</a> <a href="Juan%20Manuel%20Santos">Juan Manuel Santos</a> wrote on Twitter that: "We celebrate the democratic spirit of the United States. With Donald Trump we will continue to <a href="Colombia-United%20States%20relations">strengthen our bilateral relations</a>." 
Venezuela.
<a href="President%20of%20Venezuela">Venezuelan president</a> <a href="Nicol%C3%A1s%20Maduro">Nicolás Maduro</a> in a telephone call with <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20State">Secretary of State</a> <a href="John%20Kerry">John Kerry</a> sent a congratulatory message to both Trump and Clinton while they discussed <a href="Venezuela-United%20States%20relations">bilateral relations between both countries</a>.
Other.
<a href="Chile">Chile</a>an <a href="President%20of%20Chile">president</a> <a href="Michelle%20Bachelet">Michelle Bachelet</a> and <a href="Peru">Peru</a>vian <a href="President%20of%20Peru">president</a> <a href="Pedro%20Pablo%20Kuczynski">Pedro Pablo Kuczynski</a> sent their good wishes to Trump.
International Organizations.
Assyrian Universal Alliance.
In an open letter, the group <a href="Assyrian%20Universal%20Alliance">Assyrian Universal Alliance</a> congratulated Trump and drew his attention to what they called the ongoing genocide of Christians by the Islamic State in the Middle East and urged him to fulfill promises and help them return home. Carlo Kooktapeh Ganjeh of the US chapter of the Assyrian Universal Alliance also said: "I extend our heartfelt congratulations to you for your election as the President of the United States,"
European Union.
<a href="President%20of%20the%20European%20Council">President of the European Council</a> <a href="Donald%20Tusk">Donald Tusk</a> congratulated Trump and invited him to an EU-US summit to improve co-operation.
ISIS.
The <a href="Islamic%20State%20of%20Iraq%20and%20the%20Levant">Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant</a> (ISIL/ISIS) reportedly celebrated Trump's victory, claiming it would help strengthen recruitment and writing "Rejoice with support from <a href="Allah">Allah</a>, and find glad tidings in the imminent demise of America at the hands of Trump."
NATO.
<a href="Secretary%20General%20of%20NATO">Secretary-General</a> <a href="Jens%20Stoltenberg">Jens Stoltenberg</a>, whose organization Trump has said was "obsolete" during the campaign, said:
US leadership is as important as ever. Our Alliance has brought together America's closest friends in times of peace and of conflict for almost 70 years. A strong NATO is good for the United States, and good for Europe. We face a challenging new security environment, including hybrid warfare, cyber attacks, the threat of terrorism. NATO has responded with determination to the new security situation. But we have more work to do. And I look forward to meeting Mr. Trump soon, and welcoming him to Brussels for the NATO Summit next year to discuss the way forward.
He added: "NATO's security guarantee is a treaty commitment and all allies have made a solemn commitment to defend each other and this is something which is absolute and unconditioned." He reminded that NATO was part of <a href="Operation%20Enduring%20Freedom">Operation Enduring Freedom</a> and that NATO "is important both for collective defence in Europe and to provide help and play a role in the fight against international terrorism."
Financial markets.
The <a href="Mexican%20peso">Mexican peso</a> rallied in the day before the election on speculation Trump would lose over his alleged anti-Mexican comments, while the stock markets of the world also rallied on speculation Clinton would win. The price of gold, in turn, dropped after days of increasing for the same reason.
After the result, the <a href="United%20States%20dollar">US dollar</a> and stock markets initially sank, especially in the Asia–Pacific region which was open as the result came in. In like measure, traditional safe haven assets such as sovereign bonds and gold were higher. The Mexican peso fell about 13 percent. <a href="Dow%20Jones%20futures">Dow Jones futures</a> also fell about 3 percent. The day after the election, however, the Dow Jones rose 257 points despite the "knee-jerk reaction" of the night before. The Dow Jones continued to rise over the week, and on November 10 it reached a record high, experiencing its best week since 2011. However, unlike most other global markets, Russia's <a href="MICEX">MICEX</a> rose after the result.
In the weeks following the election, as Trump gradually formed his pro-business <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Donald%20Trump">cabinet</a>, US stock markets rallied strongly and the <a href="Dow%20Jones%20Industrial%20Average">Dow Jones Industrial Average</a> flirted with the 20,000-point level. The US dollar also gained significant value.
Media.
On November 10 the "<a href="Toronto%20Star">Toronto Star</a>" reported that the website of <a href="Immigration%2C%20Refugees%20and%20Citizenship%20Canada">Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada</a> crashed when it was flooded with a large increase in traffic on election night. The increase in traffic was said to be 5 times larger than normal, and the percent of requests coming from the United States increased from the normal ten percent to fifty percent of all requests.
North Korea's "<a href="Rodong%20Sinmun">Rodong Sinmun</a>" wrote: "It has burdened the new administration with the difficulty of facing the Juche nuclear state," referring to the North Korean state ideology often translated as "self-reliance." The article did not mention Trump by name, but declared "it was high time" that the US took action to resolve tensions on the <a href="Korean%20Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>. The editorial maintained that North Korea would never give up its nuclear weapons and referred to comments made last month by US Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, who called efforts to denuclearize North Korea a "lost cause." The publication declared Washington plans "an outdated illusion."
Academia.
"Oraib Rantawi, head of Al Quds Centre for Political Studies, said Jordan is one of the 'very few' countries that are not worried about who is the US President, as the Kingdom has maintained 'a very stable and wise relationship' with the US administration regardless of who has been in the Oval Office." Mauritian economist Rajiv Seervansingh suggested a Donald Trump administration would have both a direct and an indirect impact on the Mauritian economy and stated:
Nothing as such will change with Donald Trump being the President of the USA. We mostly deal with the USA via the AGOA. There is no direct threat to our economy. Exportations through the AGOA will continue. We still need to figure out Trump's political and economic policies. If the President-elect decides to scrap the various deals on imports, it will have a negative impact on international trade. Then Mauritius might be affected by this. If the dollar depreciates, exports will suffer as exporters will get less revenue.
Religious.
<a href="Justin%20Welby">Justin Welby</a>, the <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Canterbury">Archbishop of Canterbury</a> of the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a> and symbolic head of the <a href="Anglican%20Communion">Anglican Communion</a>, called for "reconciliation" and he also pledged to "pray for all the people of the United States." <a href="Patriarch%20Kirill%20of%20Moscow">Patriarch Kirill of Moscow</a>, the head of the <a href="Russian%20Orthodox%20Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>, offered "heartfelt congratulations" to Trump and a hope that he would bring change to American domestic and foreign policy.
Others.
Residents of Trump's ancestral home of <a href="Kallstadt">Kallstadt</a>, Germany, have expressed negative opinions of him. People from Melania Trump's hometown of <a href="Novo%20Mesto">Novo Mesto</a>, Slovenia, congratulated her for becoming the <a href="First%20Lady%20of%20the%20United%20States">first lady of the United States</a>. International protests against the election of Trump have occurred in Great Britain, the Philippines, Germany, Canada, Belgium and Australia.
